B000092ZYX|5.0|The new Radiohead album is, in my opinion, the band's best effort since 1997's OK computer.  While the album is similar to OK Computer, it retains many elements from The Bends, Kid A, and Amnesiac.  The album opens with &quot;2+2=5,&quot; AKA &quot;The Lukewarm,&quot; one of the album's strongest tracks.  The following track, &quot;Sit Down. Stand Up,&quot; is probably the album's weakest point.  &quot;Sail to the Moon&quot; is a close relative of 1997's &quot;The Tourist.&quot;  &quot;Backdrifts&quot; juxtaposes the electronica of Kid A and the deep songwriting of OK Computer and The Bends.  The song &quot;Go to Sleep&quot; sounds like it could have easily been featured on The Bends.  &quot;There There,&quot; the album's first single, is one of the best Radiohead tracks of all time.  The album ends on its highest note with the altogether wonderful &quot;A Wolf at the Door.&quot;  Overall, this is the album that fans of OK Computer have been waiting for, although it is not exactly the &quot;return to rock&quot; that the band promised.  If you are a fan of Radiohead, Hail to the Thief will not disappoint.
B000092ZYY|5.0|In anticipation to this album's release, many people hailed it as the return to guitars or even &quot;Ok Computer 2&quot;, but is that really a good thing? Sure The Bends was a great album and has stood the test of time so far, and Ok Computer was pure brilliance, but Radiohead have matured so much since then. Kid A and Amnesiac were considered experimental or &quot;weird for the sake of weird.&quot; In actuality they were skillfully orchestrated, beautiful albums. For some they may have taken a few listens to fully appreciate, but nobody I know has been dissappointed after giving them a truly open mind. Radiohead are able to use unconventional methods to create unique music that is ages beyond any band around today. I recommend this album as their best yet. Yes it is better than Ok Computer. Yes it is better than Kid A. Thom's singing is hair-raisingly beautiful (and his best yet), Phil's percussion has never been more impressive, Colin plays some of the funkiest bass lines they have ever written, Ed continues to impress with the endless amounts of beautiful soundscapes and fills, and Jonny is near Godliness with all of his musical performances. The band recorded this album in a much more stress-free and happy manner than any of their previous albums and it shows. I, for one, am very happy that the band is not returning to their &quot;roots&quot;, and is continuing to get better and better as time goes on. Hail to The Thief has only been in stores for two days and I can safely say that it is my favorite album of all time.
B000056IKU|5.0|After the relatively large success of their first album in Germany, Neu! members Michael Rother and Klaus Dinger returned to the studio with engineer Conny Plank to recorded their second album. &quot;Neu! 2&quot; starts out as a continuation of the first album. The 11-minute opening track &quot;Fur Immer&quot; is a beefier heavier take on &quot;Hallogallo&quot; from the first album. Klaus Dinger's drumbeat stays locked in place while Michael Rother's guitar swims and swerves around a stationary E-major chord. This is a fine piece of minimalist-rock. The following piece, &quot;Spitzenqualitat&quot;, focuses on &quot;Fur Immer's&quot; driving drumbeat which gradually slows down until it stops. While this is going on, various echo and electronic effects weave through the drum rhythm. This leads directly into &quot;Gedenkminute&quot; which is a full minute of wind sounds and a church bell tolling. &quot;Lila Engel&quot; closes the first half of the album with Klaus Dinger's driving drums and moaning vocals.<br />The second half of the album is where everything shifts drastically. Legend has it that while Neu! was in the middle of recording this album, they discovered that their recording budget had run out and had to finish everything in a huge rush. For this part of the album, Rother and Dinger used an early single as the basis for manipulating and stretching the music into one side of an LP. So what we have here is two tracks, &quot;Neuschnee&quot; and &quot;Super&quot; included in their original versions as well as the tracks being played back at 16 and 78 RPM. Also included is two-minutes worth a cassette being eaten in a tapedeck (&quot;Cassetto&quot;) and roughly four-minutes worth of &quot;Neuschnee&quot; being played at various speeds while Dinger, Rother and engineer Conny Plank have a conversation in the recording studio (&quot;Hallo Excentrico&quot;). The second half of &quot;Neu! 2&quot; is basically an early example of what was to become known as the remix. It's interesting hearing how these two simple tracks could be turned into an adventerous sound collage.<br />Like the first album, &quot;Neu! 2&quot; would go on to be influential to many artists in many different genres from punk to art-rock to techno. This album continues to be a timeless classic and is a highly recommended piece of German Krautrock at its very best.It's interesting hearing how these two simple tracks could be turned into an adventerous sound collage. <BR>Like the first album, &quot;Neu! 2&quot; would go on to be influential to many artists in many different genres from punk to art-rock to techno. This album continues to be a timeless classic and is a highly recommended piece of German Krautrock at its very best.

0553573403|4.0|At first, this was certainly a highly enjoyable book to read. The first several hundred pages were amazing, and exactly what I'd expected and hoped for when I picked up this book.<br />From the beginning, one main thing caught my attention and held it fast: the finding of six direwolf pups, wolf-type animals which grow to be the size of a pony. As a lover of wolves, this immediately hooked me, as they are found in the first chapter. There were six direwolves, each of them given to the children of Lord Eddard stark of Winterfell. His bastard son Jon takes the white one which he finds away from the rest of the litter, which proves to help him quite well later on. The direwolves are constant throughout the book, as it is told through the view of many characters, including most of the children. Instead of chapter numbers, \\"A Game of Thrones\\" has the chapters labeled as the name of the main character it is following. With several main characters who are being followed, oftentimes it is quite easy to come to really love certain characters, and loath others so much that you just don't want them to exist anymore. From time to time, that could keep me from reading on, but once you really get into the book and the little plot of each character begins to really take shape, you find yourself looking forward to all chapters in the book. I still had my favourites-Jon Snow, Eddard Stark, his daughter Arya, and a dwarfed man called Tyrion Lannister-but I still found all of the chapters thoroughly enjoyable once the book truly got going.<br />\\"A Game of Thrones\\" is a very well-developed book. The characters are simply amazing, the histories of the differing houses and the land well planned and intricate, and the settings clear and well-defined. The characters often have certain traits associated to their particular house, such as the Lannister pride and the Stark honor. Seeing the story from all different views does little to change opinions of certain people, as their personalities do not change from seeing them through the eyes of different people. All of the houses and families of the book have deep histories to them, often explaining certain alliances seen as tension mounts in the political system of the Seven Kingdoms. The setting of the forests seen throughout the land, and the city of King's Landing are well set in the mind throughout the book. Slightly disappointingly, the cold of the north does not seem to be mentioned very much at all, making it seem almost as if snow is warm. Still, the idea and images are easy to remember and imagine.<br />There was a point in the book where I began change my high opinion of it, to some extent. There comes a point where everything seems to come crashing down around everyone, loved characters are stabbed in the back and chance moves completely the other way. Alliances are made and broken, men betrayed, and ambition rewarded as everyone plays their hand in the game of thrones. Too bad most of the losers seem to be some of the most loveable characters. When this begins, it doesn't end until the book ends. I couldn't put the book down, but still I was rarely happy about how things were going, and ofttimes I was very saddened about what happens to certain characters.<br />It left a bit of a bitter taste in my mouth, so in the end, I just couldn't quite say it's the best I've ever read, even though it was extremely close for several hundred pages. Nevertheless, this was a very good read, and I'd suggest this to just about anyone to read. Overall this was worth the time and money, and I look forward to the rest of the series.do not change from seeing them through the eyes of different people. All of the houses and families of the book have deep histories to them, often explaining certain alliances seen as tension mounts in the political system of the Seven Kingdoms. The setting of the forests seen throughout the land, and the city of King's Landing are well set in the mind throughout the book. Slightly disappointingly, the cold of the north does not seem to be mentioned very much at all, making it seem almost as if snow is warm. Still, the idea and images are easy to remember and imagine.<br />There was a point in the book where I began change my high opinion of it, to some extent. There comes a point where everything seems to come crashing down around everyone, loved characters are stabbed in the back and chance moves completely the other way. Alliances are made and broken, men betrayed, and ambition rewarded as everyone plays their hand in the game of thrones. Too bad most of the losers seem to be some of the most loveable characters. When this begins, it doesn't end until the book ends. I couldn't put the book down, but still I was rarely happy about how things were going, and ofttimes I was very saddened about what happens to certain characters.<br />It left a bit of a bitter taste in my mouth, so in the end, I just couldn't quite say it's the best I've ever read, even though it was extremely close for several hundred pages. Nevertheless, this was a very good read, and I'd suggest this to just about anyone to read. Overall this was worth the time and money, and I look forward to the rest of the series.
B00008J4P5|3.0|I went out to buy the new Radiohead disc and while I was there I picked up White Stripes to see what the fuss is about. I appreciate the band's raw, bare-bones style and punk attitude but it isn't exactly new. Several bands such as The Velvet Underground, The B52's, The Violent Fems, and even The Beatles have done this kind of thing before. As for recording an album with just two people and a basic recording machine, Todd Rundgren did a one man album 30 years ago, writing, producing and performing the entire thing by himself. And unfortunately for White Stripes, their songwriting doesn't come close to equaling any of the artists just mentioned. The major problem here is that there's a whole lotta cool, retro, minimalist style but not much content. And we all know what style over content equals, right? It means in a couple of years the teenage kids this music appeals to will mature into new tastes and White Stripes will be long forgotten. But as a cool little retro record to pass the summer with it's not bad.

0812550706|5.0|I relaly enjoyed reading this book. it was one of the few books that got me back into reading during the summer. although it did contain elements of science fiction, if you are not a sci fi buff you will love the story and plot and especially the protagonist Ender.
0375823360|3.0|First off, I want to congratulate Philip Pullman on the <BR>scope and wonder he captures in this creative romp through<BR>many worlds. The story of Lyra and Will and their attempts<BR>to understand the universe and its nature is fun and gripping.<BR>Pullman's ability to evoke realistic worlds and images is <BR>amazing. His characters, on the whole, are interesting and <BR>compelling, and his creativity is second to none. The books<BR>attempt to deal with the great themes of philosophic and theological<br />thought: the nature of evil, the nature of redemption, the<BR>power of love, loyalty, the consequences of our actions and <BR>choices, etc. However, the overall message<BR>is fatally marred by what can only be described as the <BR>personal blind spot of the author himself.<br />In a piece of fiction that deals with multiple worlds and<BR>multiple species, one would expect there to be many, many<BR>ways of understanding the universe. And these would, presumably,<BR>hold similarities to each other in the way that the real world's <BR>great religions are similar. That is, one would expect divergence <BR>on rituals, mythologies, cosmological descriptions of origins, etc., <BR>but one would universally expect to see that the ends do not justify <BR>the means, that love, humility, charity, concern for others, etc. are extolled<BR>and taught as the greatest truths and virtues, that striving toward wisdom and<BR>communion with the sacred is a task we all share. And Pullman's trilogy <BR>_does_, to a certain extent, respect these great truths...with<BR>one incredible exception. <br />It becomes clear in The Golden Compass that Pullman equates <BR>the Catholic Church, and Christianity in general, with the <BR>very _essence_ of evil and power-grubbing authoritarianism. And near<BR>the end of the Amber Spyglass he has declared, unambiguously,<BR>that there is no God and that Christianity is a compelling but<BR>erroneous belief. He describes<BR>an institutional Church that, apparently, preaches hatred, intolerance,<BR>torture, and fananticism...really the worst caricature of the worst <BR>abuses of the Catholic church over the last two millenia. Interestingly <BR>enough, however, every _other_ religious worldview presented (secular <BR>humanism, Deism,<BR>Scientism, Shamanism, skepticism, Paganism, pragmatism, <BR>and a watered-down form of Buddhism) <BR>is seen as worthy. All beliefs about the world are shown to be valid and <BR>honorable..._except_ Christianity (and Catholicism in particular).<br />The incredible narrowness of the author's expressed <BR>hatred of Christianity may well be, as some reviewers have suggested, a personal<BR>thing. And I have no doubt that Mr. Pullman is entitled to his<BR>beliefs. But the very zealotry that he seems to display in his hatred<BR>of Christianity is the very _essence_ of what his protagonists profess to <BR>hate about the Catholic church...their intolerance, their inability<BR>to see beyond their own closely-held worldview, the \\"rightness\\" of<BR>their point of view versus everyone else's.<br />I don't believe this book tries to \\"take down\\" Christianity per se, <BR>although one could argue that Pullman tries to do just that. But <BR>I believe because of Mr. Pullman's own confused moral sense and <BR>bigotry, the books seem to show an incredibly lopsided view of what the universe<BR>looks like. Lying, cheating, killing are all fine and have no long-term<BR>consequences, according to Pullman, if the ends are worthy enough; you don't<BR>even have to regret the wrongs you to do others along the way (witness<BR>the ironically Christian-like redemption of Lyra's parents at the end of the <BR>trilogy, despite their collective torture and killing of innocents). <BR>Morals are all relative, and all philosophies of the nature of life are <BR>fine, just as long as they aren't Catholic. <br />Deep truths abound in these books, but they always seem just out of reach <BR>of its author, and thus, out of reachof the reader. We never seem to know <BR>what the point of the journey was, unless it was just the fun of the ride. <BR>But this moral confusion and undisguised bias against all things Christian <BR>takes what _could_ have been a great trilogy...even a saga of the magnitude <BR>and scope of Tolkien's \\"Lord of the Rings\\", and reduces it to a moral muddle. <br />What a shame.

B00008G9JO|2.0|Hmm....Well, I don't know. I'm inclined to consider Weathercock, for example, a song about...a weathercock. Okay, like the songs having to do with animals, this song having to do with an inanimate non-animal also anthopomophises, but that's pretty much it for imagination. (&quot;Rasping&quot; aside, the singing here and elsewhere strikes me as rather inanimate itself.) Speaking of Weathercock, its refrain is home to one of those &quot;rare melodic bits&quot; (or however it was put) we occasionally find on this album. Its verse basically drones in turn on one of three pitches, with pentatonic embellishment and only vestigial harmonic accompaniment. The &quot;rare melodic bit&quot; I'm thinking of is a pentatonic neume above a supertonic triad preceded by the (major) tonic triad on &quot;Sing to us softly; hum evening's song&quot;. For better or worse, you've heard something very like this many times before. Conversely, the bit that makes me cringe (especially the second time when &quot;Tell us how the blacksmith...&quot; becomes &quot;Point the way to...&quot;) comes directly after: a lowered leading-tone major triad preceded by the dominant triad, which seems to ME (not necessarily to you) jarring, crude, and unrelated to what came directly before.<br />Let's also mention briefly some things this album does RIGHT. 1) David Palmer is writing for actual strings again. (The electronic imitations on Songs From The Wood were rather annoying.) 2) Ian Anderson IS in good voice on the lyrical section of Heavy Horses (the song)--if not elsewhere. 3) John Evan's piano accompaniment here is especially appealing.

B00008LDPU|4.0|A lot of other reviewers have already commented on how the Wachowski Brothers borrow heavily from anime and manga to create The Matrix. They now complete the circle with The Animatrix.<br />THE ANIMATRIX is a series of short animated films from several Japanese anime directors (and a couple of American ones as well). I call attention to the now 15+ year old ROBOT CARNIVAL, which is a Japanese movie composed of a series of animated short pieces strung together by the narrative hook of robots. Perhaps not surprisingly, there is an overlap as Kouji Morimoto directed bits for both films (\\"Franken's Gear\\" in Robot Carnival and \\"Beyond\\" in The Animatrix).<br />The Animatrix does succeed in extending Matrix universe by allowing other creative minds to play with the setting. \\"Final Flight of the Orsiris\\", essentially a prologue to Matrix Reloaded, is from the creators of the beautifully rendered but soul-less Final Fantasy: The Spirits Within. As the closest thing to \\"film\\" in The Animatrix, it makes for a nice bridge between this animated and the theatrical release. (Okay, I admit I wasn't sure if they were CG-characters or rotoscoped at first.) As animation, it is nothing new or special.<br />My favorites of the short films are \\"The Second Renaissance\\", Parts I and II. There is some filling of the backstory on the history of Men and Machines. It also makes the best use of anime as a mirror for reality. Another piece I really liked was \\"Matriculated\\" from Aeon Flux creator Peter Chung. The idea of humans kidnapping and reprogramming machines by seducing them with fleshy pleasures is the closest The Animatrix come to extending (and inverting) the metaphor of the Matrix.<br />The other story which is most scifi is \\"Beyond\\". Here, in a glitch in the Matrix creates a \\"haunted house\\" in the midst of a Tokyo (?) burb. It is also the most fantastical story with a classic (cliche?) twist ending. For me, \\"Beyond\\" is childlike and plain delightful.<br />\\"Kid's Story\\" and \\"World Record\\" are cool enough vignettes of other humans in the Matrix. Stylistically, they very much echo anime conventions. They don't add new understanding to the Matrix, however. <br />The one piece that could have and should have dealt with the whole \\"blue pill/red pill\\" dichotomy is \\"Program\\". Here, a recruit is tempted by her trainer/handler to return to the Matrix. It could have been an interesting extension of humans choosing between the discomfort of reality vs the faux-paradise of the Matrix. Instead, \\"Program\\" is merely a battle between two humans. Thus \\"Program\\" is merely an animated rendering of a film apeing anime conventions. (Echoes of Scary Movie/Scream/teen slasher movies, anyone?)

B000092ZYX|5.0|If you have been worried about 'Hail To The Thief' living up to the impossibly high standards that only Radiohead can achieve, I'm here to let you know your worries are unfounded. Many complain that Radiohead are oft judged based on the merits/sounds of their previous works, and personally I don't appreciate the rampant \\"'The Bends'/'OK Computer'\\" comparisons made so often when a new album of theirs comes out. Honestly, however, Radiohead are a band which in their own overt way are so far removed from other musicians (although there ARE links if you look hard enough, like Autchere, Aphex Twin, Miles Davis, Smiths, Pixies, REM, etc.) that they become a specific type of beast, one which can only be put into perspective with their own works ('Pablo Honey', their first effort, notwithstanding). And yes, their new record shares much with the groundbreaking albums which preceded it, 'Kid A' and to a lesser extent 'Amnesiac' with its affinity for computer-generated soundscapes and intricate, methodic pacing.<BR>But it, like Radiohead itself, emerges after several listens to be a beast of its own.<br />In its musical impact, lyrical sentiments and overall relevance HTTT emerges as being their most direct and technically \\"pop\\" record ever, even more so than Pablo Honey. Thom Yorke has always claimed this would be a much more accessible record, and it shows from the first moments in \\"2+2=5.\\" The song is by no means mainstream, lowbrow, or simplistic, yet it resonates with an impact that Radiohead's music (at least recently) hasn't shown. The drum machine at the beginning comes off as nervous, organic, real, rather than cold and frosty as it usually comes across with their music. Yorke's plaintive cries, Jonny Greenwood and Ed O'Brien's guitars, and Colin Greenwood's bass undertones are crisp, dry, immediate. Phil Selway's drums pummel with force. Even though this song has all the intricacy of Kid A and Amnesiac, it carries little of the subtlety. To wit, it hits you like a brick.<br />Rather than giving the record some time to age and unfold itself, HTTT tries to capture a more live, energetic performance of Radiohead's. It resembles the overlooked road album New Adventures in Hi-Fi by REM in that it tries to capture the intensity of the moment. Instrumentation flows naturally into electronic soundscapes. The skitter of electronic pulses on \\"Sit Down Stand Up\\" break perfectly into pounding drums, Yorke's mantra of \\"The Raindrops,\\" and driving, forceful bass. \\"Myxomatosis\\" later on buzzes with all the warmth of a saw, it's towering synth line knocking you hard into your seat, like the relentlessness of the media it chronicles. Yorke has maintained themes of looming darkness, hopelessness, control, fear for our future, and on here they ram them home with the force of importance. While Kid A and Amnesiac were more obscure treatisies on the state of our world and all the paranoia, madness, loss and hope it implies, Hail to the Thief is a (slightly) more focused statement. What they say here, they mean passionately, and they don't want to waste time. This is war, on Radiohead's terms. Pop music forms are a means to the end.<br />This record also takes a direction that other Radiohead records haven't, and gives it further identity: warmth. Camp and even almost sensual mood pieces abound, such as \\"Go to Sleep,\\" \\"We Suck Young Blood,\\" and \\"A Punch-Up at a Wedding,\\" which manages to lay a thick piano and bass guitar groove over vaguely political lyrics. The voice of Yorke is clear, impassioned, and equal parts hissing and soothing. The more wholly electronic experiments, \\"Backdrifts\\" (the best song on here) and \\"The Gloaming\\" benefit from the tones of his voice, the earlier a plea to succeed even as one knows one is doomed to failure, the later an almost Grimm fairy tale style musing on approaching darkness, sung almost mantra-like. People complained about the inclusion of electronic textures before. They will find here how wrong they are: Radiohead have mastered the genre and techniques and prove they can manufacture fantastic compositions no matter what the medium.<br />Overflowing in warmth, purpose, and importance, already it can be seen that this has a strong chance at becoming Album of the Year. With most of Radiohead's records my proper reccomendation if you're wary would be to \\"spend time with it, let it try to grow on you.\\" I have a feeling, though, that if this one doesn't bowl you over on first listen, you probably don't deserve the pleasure of appreciating good music. There's too much here to be stuck nay-saying. Either hop on board or get out of the way.

B000092ZYX|5.0|.. A few weeks back, when \\"Hail to the Thief\\" was first announced, I thought to myself, \\"If it is in fact a good album, Radiohead will have created something of rather singular achievement: the worst title for a significant work of art in the history of the Western tradition.\\" For better or worse, Radiohead have failed to rise to that challenge. \\"Hail to the Thief\\" is not a bad set of songs (I'd certainly rather listen to it than to the majority of new releases), but it lacks magic in the same sense that the title \\"Hail to the Thief\\" lacks magic compared to the humor and literacy of \\"OK Computer\\". Like its title, Thief accomplishes exactly what it sets out to do, creating musically sophisticated songs of vague social topicality, but it fails to go beyond that point. Though title and songs \\"fit\\" in an external sense (that is, they sound like what smart, hip culture is supposed to sound like), they lack an internal depth that is the heart of art.<br />The first track, 2+2=5, demonstrates the aesthetic shallowness of the album quite clearly. A dynamic tour de force with the central line of \\"YOU HAVE NOT BEEN PAYING ATTENTION\\", it has all the surface elements of a great rock song and yet none of the feeling of great music. On a technical level, its transition from the opening melody of \\"two and two always make a five\\" to the heterogeneous punk wailing of \\"hail to the thief, oh, hail to the thief- but I'm not!\\" is quite impressive. On the latter bit, listeners are also treated to a few gorgeous, classic Radiohead synth effects. Furthermore, the theme is clear and relevant: politicians have lulled the public into accepting the fallacious and fascistic logic behind their \\"crusade for freedom\\" for too long. So what's the problem? There is, in fact, a big problem: 2+2=5 has no soul, no internal logic. The political sentiments are true, but bland, the sort that are easy to agree with (or disagree, for that matter) because they proclaim party allegiance rather than present a personal view. And, though the three melodies are novel and expertly blended, they also have nothing to do with each other. There's no particular musical connection between the beginning and the end of the song, only an incidental one. Reflecting on where it ends reveals nothing about where it begins, and vice versa. 2+2=5 is still certainly a solid rock song, and should still send music geeks to their keyboards. Listeners yearning for the sublimely orchestrated soundscapes of OK Computer and Kid A (or Quadrophenia, or Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band, or Tristan und Isolde, or Verdi's Requiem, etc...), however, should search elsewhere.<br />Not that there aren't a few memorable tunes. Where I End and You Begin has a nice sense of dynamics and background synthesizer interplay, resulting in song that feels very complete from beginning to end. Scatterbrain is a sweet, simply structured melody performed with just enough gusto to make it the next single. As befits a maturing band, the softer songs are also getting mighty pretty: Sail to the Moon, We suck Young Blood, I Will; these have the gentle touch of true feeling. The latter especially is an example of true, classical song-craft. With three voices soaring around a single, subdued guitar, it reminded me more of Schubertian lieder than anything one could hear on the radio. The song is preceded by the fantastic single, There There, which sees the band engaging a fairly standard rock structure with perhaps the best developed melody on the album. With something like a chorus, a triple-guitar/triple-drum orchestration that actually expands the logic of the melodic progression, and what is almost a guitar solo by Johnny near the end, There There manages to be both the most superficially conservative and the most fundamentally creative track on the album. On the seven-odd minutes in which I Will follows There There, \\"Hail to the Thief\\" briefly becomes the great rock album that it promised to be. As it actually is, however, the whole is a thoroughly professional, engagingly musical, and socially aware piece of popular entertainment. And nothing more.

0783225857|5.0|We watched this DVD once again, but on a note of sadness.<br />We mourn Gregory Peck's passing, June 12, 2003.<br />Look no further than this film for the full measure of his talent, and a good glimpse at the kind of man he was in real life. It is fitting that he lived just long enough to know of the honor bestowed on his character Atticus Finch, named Greatest Hero in film by the American Film Institute .  While mortal in life, he is immortal in film. So long, Greg!<br />This DVD treats this classic film very well indeed, though some will always want for more extra features.  The picture is beautiful, the sound is good, the \\"making-of\\" retrospective is wonderful -- a must for your film library!  I'm not sure why they put colorized stills on the DVD box cover; it is a black and white film, but please don't let that stop you!<br />I have always thought this film deserved a better place on AFI's list of top films than #34, such as the top 10. It is as fine a two-hour distillation of Harper Lee's great American novel as you could ever ask for -- a beautiful, elegant film that exactly captures the spirit and essence of time and place and character. Fabulous direction, photography, editing, writing, acting, and music come together seamlessly in a perfect, tight fabric. It is an astounding achievement in screenplay based on such a novel.  Of course the novel is far better, more complete, but it is a great film on its own merits.<br />Harper Lee shows us the beauty and contradictions and ugliness in Southern culture as no one has before or since. She shows us her disappointment in and revulsion of aspects of her white Southern heritage, while at the same time showing us her great pride in a culture that is so rich and so beautiful when it throws off the ugly cloak of hatred and discrimination (take note, all ye \\"proud\\" wavers of the Confederate battle flag). Human arrogance and selfishness have wrought such evils, in this case from slavery to civil war to the desire for vengeance and scapegoats, often (and still) in the name of God. Let us learn from our history, improve ourselves, and sin no more.<br />Buy this film, watch this film, love this film.  Be Atticus Finch!or vengeance and scapegoats, often (and still) in the name of God. Let us learn from our history, improve ourselves, and sin no more. <br />Buy this film, watch this film, love this film.  Be Atticus Finch!

B000092ZYX|4.0|Thom Yorke has described Hail to the Thief as &quot;OK Computer 2&quot;, and in many ways it does give a tip of the hat to their 1997 masterpiece.  But back then, when the Oxford quintet was searching for new ways to express themselves both musically and lyrically, they were travelling new ground on an uncharted course.  Three albums and six years later, Thom and company have become mega-stars and inspired a host of followers and imitators, and their impact has been so great on the musical landscape that they seem sometimes to be competing against their previous efforts. It ain't easy, after all, to continue being cutting edge and inventive.<BR>&quot;Hail to the Thief&quot; continues Radiohead's exploration of the isolation, disillusionment and compartmentalization of modern society, with stories of helplessness in the face of repression, loneliness and yearnings in the face of overwhelming odds, be they personal, political or ethical.<BR>The album opens with &quot;2+2=5&quot;, in which the boys demonstrate that they can still strap on their guitars and rock, and &quot;There There&quot;  is a radio-friendly slice of pulsating drums and urgent riffing.  &quot;Sail to the Moon&quot; is perhaps their most beautiful ballad in years, with lovely piano accompaniment.  &quot;Backdrifts&quot; and &quot;Where I End and You Begin&quot; are haunting, melodic pieces that express Radiohead's ability to fully orchestrate a song without the bombast and overly-produced excess to which most bands may have fallen prey.<BR>&quot;A Punchup at a Wedding&quot; gives us a beautiful little piano dittie puncuated by a scathing diatribe against a boorish fool, and &quot;A Wolf at the Door&quot; ends the record on a dark, disturbing note.<BR>Fans of modern electronica may find &quot;The Gloaming&quot;, &quot;Myxomatosis&quot;  and other bits on Hail to be a tad wanting when compared to true masters of the genre, but they do entertain nonetheless.<BR>Taken as a whole, &quot;Hail...&quot; is anaccomplished work by a band that's at a crossroads; They've mastered their craft, yet they continue to search for new means by which to express themselves.  &quot;Hail to the Thief&quot; will probably not garner the band many new fans, as it's neither as lush, rich and rewarding as OK Computer, nor as challenging and aloof as Kid A, but this album should still give their fans a satisfying record that takes many a listening to fully appreciate the intricacies and nuances of a highly accomplished artistic talent.  If it is, as it sounds, a bit of a step back from &quot;Amnesiac&quot; and &quot;Kid A&quot; toward the more comfortable &quot;OK Computer&quot;, it begs the question, &quot;What's Next?&quot;

0393057658|5.0|This book will really appeal to hardcore baseball fans who've embraced the conclusions of Bill James and his proteges.  Lewis has a very readable style, and he doesn't shy away from some of the more complicated aspects of baseball analysis.  He includes a nice history of cutting edge thinking on the subject of baseball analysis that reveals that Bill James wasn't (and isn't) the only voice crying out in the desert.  Also, there are anecdotes involving contemporary players and coaches that demonstrate the gulf between how players and analysts view the game.  As you may have heard, Billy Beane doesn't come off in the most flattering light, but it's a credit to Beane that he didn't seek to edit unfavorable content as well as to Lewis for keeping this content in the book.  It's a fast read and interesting to boot.

B00000DQSV|3.0|Duran Duran is a band that has rarely summoned the energy or self-respect to make a completely worthwhile, high quality record. Though they've been making albums since 1981, only three of them (\\"Duran Duran I,\\" \\"Rio,\\" and \\"Medazzaland\\") have been excellent from start to finish.<br />Their laziness is on display here. \\"Notorious\\" was released in 1986, after the departure of guitarist Andy Taylor and drummer Roger Taylor, and can be seen as a product of the opposing creative visions of bassist John Taylor and keyboardist Nick Rhodes. During 1985, Duran had been split into two camps, with John and Andy making a dismal attempt at white funk with the abominable Power Station, while Nick, Simon, and Roger made the elegant and beautifully arranged \\"So Red the Rose\\" under the name Arcadia. When Duran reformed, this time as a trio, the collaboration produced \\"Notorious,\\" which works when Nick tempers John's funk pretensions with his arranging and keyboard skills; when John's ideas are at the fore, this album sinks miserably.<br />The title track is a brilliant funk exercise, with a sparse hook courtesy of Nile Rodgers' guitar and Nick's keyboards. Simon LeBon contributes both a fine vocal and a witty lyric. The second song, \\"American Science,\\" is an absolute tour-de-force, with Nick's understated synths finding a passionate complement in Warren Cuccurullo's searing, virtuousic guitar work (Rodgers and Cuccurullo share guitar duties on the album with Andy Taylor). \\"Skin Trade\\" is a sublime mixture of John's funk with Nick's lush musicality, and features fantastic singing from LeBon. Notable here, as on every track on \\"Notorious,\\" is Steve Ferrone's drumming, which is superb in its timing and precision; then again, it needed to be, considering the fact that he was standing in for Roger Taylor, one of rock's finest drummers.<br />\\"A Matter of Feeling\\" is a fine ballad, with an interesting keyboard arrangement from Nick and an excellent lyric and performance from Simon. From here on, however, the album is a decidedly mixed bag. \\"Hold Me\\" is reasonably good filler, but its arrangement has dated it. \\"Vertigo (Do the Demolition)\\" is a good track, despite its dumb lyric, but is followed by a truly embarrassing slice of poseur soul, \\"So Misled,\\" which has \\"skip me\\" written all over it.<br />Unfortunately, worse is still to come. \\"'Meet el Presidente'\\" is painfully bad, with a surplus of horns that fail to compensate for its compositional shortcomings and unbelievably stupid lyric. For some odd reason, they released this as a single, and it bombed in the US and barely scraped the Top 30 in the UK. \\"Winter Marches On\\" goes a long way toward redeeming this album, however, and evokes the best moments of Arcadia; this song bears the fingerprints of Nick, who amply displays his songwriting and arranging gifts here. Finally, \\"Proposition\\" ends the album on another weak note; though better than \\"So Misled\\" and \\"'Meet el Presidente,'\\" this still sounds like half-assed, pedestrian '80s pop/rock filler to me.<br />All in all, \\"Notorious\\" is a not-altogether successful merging of two pop sensibilities. Making it only to #12 on the US album charts, it officially marked the end of Duranmania. Warren Cuccurullo would continue to do session work and tour with the band before officially joining for 1990's disastrous \\"Liberty,\\" an album which is roughly equivalent in quality to this one. Their best work, however, was still ahead of them: 1997's extraordinary \\"Medazzaland.\\" Check that one out.

B000092ZYX|5.0|OK Computer interested many with its forward-looking, Orwellian paranoia.  Now September 11th has released people from the dream-world that gripped them during the 90s--a dream-world of infinite technological innovation, security, and a weightless stock market that seemed to be sailing to the moon, so to speak.  Hail to the Thief is an album that speaks directly to the world now, because of both the massive change in understanding and the evolution of Radiohead's sound.  Although for many, OK Computer still ranks as the best Radiohead album (and the best album of all time to a dedicate bunch), Hail to the Thief, with its deep symbolic resonances, simultaneous timeliness and timelessness, and aural beauty, offers a significant challenge. B00008LDPU|5.0|The Animatrix was always something I intended to pick up, but after I had more cash. While I love the Matrix, the semi-disappointment of Matrix Reloaded and the over-barrage of media hype that came with it made me want to lay off anything Matrix-related for awhile. But when I found the Animatrix for an exceptionally low price, I decided to snatch it up now rather than pay more later. And I'm glad I did.<br />I've browsed the other reviews here and a lot of anime/DVD sites, and can understand how the hardcore anime community might dislike the Animatrix. Some really bad dialogue seems to creep in now and then, and there are probably a lot more than the few anime cliches I picked up on (the feudal Japan training sim in the short \\"Program\\" is the most blatent one). However, this release still blew me away. For someone whose anime experience has been limited to watered-down American dubs like Pokemon, Yu-Gi-Oh, and Ultimate Muscle, the animation in these shorts is jaw-dropping. Mind-blowing. Certain art styles fans will like more than others, but all of them have the high detail of anime AND the fluidity of American animation. It's the best of both cultures, and like the old saying goes, \\"I never knew it could be this way.\\" On a side note, also to be commended is \\"Final Flight of the Osiris\\", the non-anime short that uses the \\"Final Fantasy\\" CGI graphics. I never saw Final Fantasy, and while the animation here was incredible, it still looked CG to me. However, certain shots of the main character(the Asian girl) looked so real I'd have sworn she was a live actor. Kudos to Square for making me believe.<br />As for the quality of the actual stories, I agree with the majority in that the four outstanding ones are Osiris, Second Renaissance I and II, and Detective Story. The others are open to a bit more criticism, and will each have their share of supporters and detractors, but I enjoyed all of them, and find that all the shorts are worth owning. Some great supplements are included too, including commentaries and an informative documentary on the history of anime. Either way, there's enough good stuff here for all anime fans to justify adding it to their collection. And if you love the Matrix, but think of anime only in terms of Pokemon, then I highly recommend you snag this eye-opening disc; you'll never view anime the same way again.ncluded too, including commentaries and an informative documentary on the history of anime. Either way, there's enough good stuff here for all anime fans to justify adding it to their collection. B000092ZYX|4.0|Been following Radiohead's musical adventures for some time now, and I've always admired how they've never tried to relive past glories, never making another Bends or writing another radio-ready &quot;Creep&quot;-styled song. I got 'Hail..' home and listened to it on headphones; from a technical standpoint it's probably the most amazing-sounding thing they have recorded. The production is flawless. <br />The material, on the other hand...It's a little hit and miss. For every swoony, accessable song (accessable for Radiohead) like 'Sail To The Moon', there's the droning electronics of a track like 'The Gloaming', a song that probably won't endear them to many new listeners. I like how the song 'Sit Down. Stand Up' winds up and explodes into a techno groove. 'Go To Sleep' and 'I Will' actually recall some of the old side of Radiohead in their melodies and arrangements, while Thom's vocals on 'A Wolf at the Door' chart new territory for the band. As an album, 'Hail To The Thief' feels more complete and cohesive than either &quot;KID A&quot;  or &quot;Amnesiac' did.

B00006F7S4|5.0|Beck's work has been all over the map, from his simple guitar based, slacker-folk beginnings to his Dust Brothers assisted dabblings with electronic sounds.  Mellow Gold, Odelay, Mutations, Midnite Vultures, each was different.  Sea Change is another turn, although this time it's not such a new direction.  It's somewhat like a culmination of Mellow Gold's guitar-strumming with the production values of his latest albums. Even with the downcast lyrics, the result if beautiful to listen to. His depression over losing his long-time girlfriend is channeled into gems like &quot;The Golden Age&quot; where electronic noise underscores Beck's wounded singing.  &quot;Lost Cause&quot; and &quot;Paper Tiger&quot; are similarily sad and mellow, but still manage to possess a vibrant energy.  The album owes alot to the superb production of Nigel Godrich who fills many of the tracks with searing strings and floating sounds.  Having said that, it's still very much Beck's album. And it's one of the best I've heard in recent years.

B000002UB3|5.0|Contrary to popular belief, the Beatles did not make Abbey Road amongst viscious infighting. Rather, the album was recorded as a last hurrah, reuniting them with George Martin as Producer. The result is perhaps the best thing the Beatles ever did.<BR> There's Lennon's avant garde brilliance on 'Come Together' and 'I Want You (She's So Heavy)', McCartney's twisted whimsy on 'Maxwell's Silver Hammer' and even Ringo's attempt at Yellow Submarine 2, with 'Octopus' Garden'. But it's George Harrison's songwriting that stands out here, finally stepping into the limelight with 2 of the albums best tracks: 'Something' and 'Here Comes the Sun'.<BR> Having said that, the \\"Medley\\" that dominates side 2 of the original album is what makes Abbey Road the legendary farewell record it was meant to be. Paul and John move back and forth between songs such as the wonderful 'You Never Give Me Your Money' and the amusing 'Mean Mr. Mustard'. The Medley moves into epic proportions with 'Golden Slumbers and 'Carry that Weight' eventually moving into a fitting trade-off featuring all 4 beatles getting a chance to solo. The album climaxes on 'The End' where the immortal final words ring home the message that the Beatles embodied. \\"In the end/the love you take/ is equal to the love you make.\\"<BR>This is a beauteous end to a mythic career. Abbey Road is perhaps the greatest album of all time.

B000002I2M|5.0|L.A. WOMAN is the sixth and last studio album recorded by The Doors. Amazon has dubbed it an \\"essential\\" recording. I wouldn't argue with that. While it isn't my personal favorite Doors album, it's close. MORRISON HOTEL, their fifth album, saw the band turn to basics with a more bluesy, hard rock approach than on previous efforts. That trend was carried even further on L.A. WOMAN. While the album's hit single, \\"Love Her Madly\\", has a smooth, commercial sound, the rest of the cuts range from cryptic and edgy to dark and gritty. Titles like \\"Been Down So Long\\", \\"Cars Hiss By My Window\\" and \\"Crawling King Snake\\" are more the norm. Jim Morrison's vocals have a gravelly and world-weary quality, but it works well in the context of his lyrics, which are sometimes brilliant. And, while the band turns in some nice instrumental work behind Morrison, the spotlight and mood are clearly his. \\"Riders On The Storm\\" is the Lizard King's eloquent and masterful swan song.<br />L.A. WOMAN is another outstanding album by one of classic rock's greatest bands. It also is apparently the best-selling Doors album. That surprises me, given that \\"Light My Fire\\" (off the first album) is probably the band's best-known song and was an enormous hit. It seemed at the time that almost everybody had a copy of that first album. That L.A. WOMAN outsold the other Doors records says something about how good it is. Most of the songs have a gritty and almost primal blues sound, and the performance is excellent. There isn't a dud anywhere. This is a genuine classic and something most blues and rock fans will want to have.

6305014140|5.0|Three movies--Akira, Ghost In The Shell and Ninja Scroll--each broke new ground and pushed the genre in the mainstream. \\"Ninja Scroll\\" is the most fun and watchable of these efforts, and despite the fact that it was released in 1996, continues to be among, if not THE best, in ninja/swordsmanship movies.<br />This is one of those \\"three-watchers\\": watch once to get acquainted, twice to fully understand, and three times to get the full effect. You could very well leave impressed after your first viewing, but numerous viewings reveal more and more each time.<br />Wandering ninja Jubei Kibagami (based on a popular swordsman of Japanese lore) is drawn into a battle with the Eight Devils of Kimon, with the beautiful and lethal Kagero on his side, as well as a government agent. Jubei must survive battles with each of the Devils--a rock-skinned hulk, a blind swordsman, a portable wasp hive, a snake-controller, a re-animator/shadow manipulator, a wire-toting electrecutor, an explosives expert and a resurrectable boss--all the while attempting to solve a mystery revolving around gold, murdered villagers and a mysterious plague.<br />The animation is top-notch. It isn't thin and computer-like, as in Ghost in the Shell, but it's as close as you can get to a moving Marvel or Image Comic. Everything is lightning fast and no sounds are wasted: you'll notice every chirping bird or falling leaf with the tension that this film builds. The shots are masterfully beautiful--a charging Jubei is shown via reflection on the blind swordsman's sword held close to his face--and the animation is consistent throughout.<br />Not to confuse what you might have heard--the violence is extremely graphic, not the sex scenes. The sex scenes are nothing worse than what an R-rated flick might produce, but the violence is up there in the level of \\"Gladiator\\" or \\"Saving Private Ryan,\\" but it's not something that goes throughout the movie so much so that it becomes disgusting.<br />The English dub is passable, capturing both Jubei's calm confidence as well as Kagero's fire, but like most anime, the Japanese version is the superior. The storyline remains generally the same in either version, although there are some significant, but not plot-disturbing, differences between the English and Japanese versions.<br />Each \\"Devil\\" is unique and cleverly thought-out, each a challenging fighter. Jubei is an anti-hero, reluctant to join the fight, and scraps his way through battles, using his smarts as well as his steel.<br />Definitely recommended for older fans, anime fan or not. It has anime's cliche graphic violence and nudity, but its plot, vocal performance and direction are excellent, among the best ever for the genre. Five stars doesn't do it justice.

B000092ZYX|5.0|Radiohead is one of those rare bands these days whose recording careers progress forward into uncharted territory. The music has a distinct 'indie' feel which is refreshing for a major-label release, and, of course, is what makes Radiohead so unique. B000092ZYX|4.0|Thom Yorke has said in recent interviews that Hail to the Thief will be the last album from Radiohead as you know them.  Two years from now, he predicted, Radiohead will reemerge completely unrecognizable.  Given that Radiohead could release a blank CD and have the world salivate over it, the possibilities of Yorke's prophecy inspire both wonder and fear.  Funny that the band's new CD, Hail to the Thief, should do the exact same thing.  <br />Here it is, Radiohead fans - the final cumulative effort from the most original rock band in decades.  Thief sounds nothing like The Bends, OK Computer, Kid A, or Amnesiac.  Thief sounds everything like The Bends, OK Computer, Kid A, or Amnesiac.  It is warm.  It is cold.  It is accessible.  It is inscrutable.  It is gorgeous.  It is terrifying.  It is immediate.  It is distant.  And, above all else, it is fascinating.  For the people (okay, everybody) hoping Radiohead might warm up after their Kid A/Amnesiac double dose of nihilism, Thief does just that.  But it does even more.  Thief isn't another OK Computer.  If you want that, you may want to listen to... OK Computer (that is why it exists in the first place).  Instead, Thief is a cohesive mishmash of The Bends' immediacy, OK's layered guitar wails, and Kid A/Amnesiac's electronic gurgling.  The critical thing is that Radiohead, as a band, have improved in all those musical approaches, and the result is their most sonically diverse album yet.  Looking for proof?  Just consult &quot;2+2=5&quot;, a slow brooding echo chamber that, midway through, blasts into an electric-guitar fury that sounds like, of all things, a Pearl Jam song.  Or try &quot;Sit Down.  Stand Up.&quot;, a forbidding piano haunter that slowly and sickeningly crescendos into an electronic hailstorm.<br />Those two songs encapsulate all the power and dread Radiohead can generate, and that's only the first eight minutes of the album.  It speaks volumes of Radiohead that Thief is considered a &quot;sunny&quot;album, given that its mood falls just somewhere short of Suicidal.  But after the stark minimalism of Kid A/Amnesiac (two records so bleak you practically expected them to create a black hole in the universe), the trace of humanity Radiohead injects into Thief makes all the difference.  There's - gasp! - an acoustic song (&quot;Go to Sleep&quot;).  And Thief's best song, &quot;A Punch-Up at a Wedding&quot;, even dabbles in piano-tinged soul.  <br />What keeps all of Thief's pieces together is Yorke's one-of-a-kind voice.  Yorke has always sounded like a ghost from the netherworld, returning to warn you about the evils of mankind.  But Kid A and Amnesiac distorted his voice even further, depriving it of its immediacy without adding to its eerie qualities (except on Kid A's title track, the only Radiohead song I personally can't stand).  Here, Yorke's voice is more or less left alone, and it accents the texture of both the guitars and the electronic blips and quirks, particularly on companion pieces &quot;The Gloaming&quot; &amp; &quot;Backdrifts&quot;.<br />The band is also allowed to flex their muscles.  Freakouts likes &quot;2+2=5&quot; are accompanied by slow crunchers like &quot;There There,&quot; the lead single, and elegantly personal songs like &quot;Where I End and You Begin&quot; and &quot;Scatterbrain&quot;.  There's no lack of experimentation - &quot;Myxomatosis&quot; sounds like an orchestra of giant zippers, and &quot;Wolf at the Door&quot; is Radiohead's first Dylan homage - but all of it is exciting and never off-putting.<br />One could argue that Thief doesn't contain a signature moment of brilliance, such as &quot;Paranoid Android&quot; or &quot;Pyramid Song&quot;.  But it's the kind of album that reveals itself to you in new ways every time you listen to it.  Overall, it accomplishes the impossible - resurrecting the best of the old while refining the new.  And regardless of where they go from here, the one guarantee is that Radiohead will continueto go in directions that inspire surprise and amazement.
B000092ZYX|5.0|For years, since Radiohead's musical masterpiece OK Computer came out, people (especially the so-called \\"hardcore\\" fans of the band) have been fantasizing about them making another OK Computer, it gets pretty boring listening to these people reviewing Radiohead's subsequent albums and comparing them with it. Thom Yorke and company somehow foresaw this after the success of Computer, and stepped away from the album's formula -or any other formula, for that instance- and delivered two of the most beautifully bizarre albums in music: Kid A and Amnesiac. The first bore absolutely no resemblance to its predecessor, which helped the band avoid the silly comparisons, yet, when the later was released, everyone jumped at the idea of Radiohead being \\"back on track\\". Somehow, the electronic element in Radiohead's music suited poeple fine but everyone still wanted another OK Computer. Shame on you! Why compare works that are so intensely apart from each other? enough with the need for references. Isn't evolution what music is all about? Imagine Bjrk trying to make Vespertine a little more, say...      \\"Debut-esque\\". What would be the point???!!! <BR>Now, Radiohead have released Hail To The Thief, an album with -yes- more guitars in it than the previous two albums. However, this should be no reason for misleading listeners by telling them it's a return to the Ok Computer-era. Nope kids, this is futuristic music in its purest form, taking elements from electronica, guitar rock, and more. Every single song is a departure from anything done actually in music; and Yorke's captivating voice is certain to take you to higher places, no matter what track you're listening to. <BR>Considering all the reviews, and without even knowing it, I gave Thief its first listen seeking any reminiscence of OK Computer I could find; suddenly, I realized my mistake, and did what any MUSIC fan ought to do: I opened my mind and heard this album for what it is, a NEW Radiohead album, and it was only thenthat I fully understood the brilliance of this musical masterpiece; I listen to many different styles of music, and Radiohead never cease to amaze me. Despite what everyone keeps saying over and over again, each album represents a full reinvention for the band. So please, NO MORE COMPARISONS! <BR>If you have taken the time to read this far, I advice you this: Take NO advice considering Radiohead! Just get this album NOW! Because if you don't already own it, you might be missing out on one of the standards by which music will be measured in the future.
B00005B4GU|4.0|After Radiohead released &quot;Kid A&quot; in 2000, the band promised a return to guitars(they finally went back for this year's &quot;Hail to the Thief&quot;), many fans felt a bit discouraged when a second record filled with experimentations and electronics would come out less than a year after &quot;Kid A&quot;. Despite some shortcomings, there's still some good moments on here to warrant a listen.<br />Packt like Sardines in a Crushd Tin Box: The album opens with what almost sounds like dishes clanging, accompanied by a descending bass riff and repeated guitar note. The normally falsetto-like Thom has a more deeper voice for this one. One of my favorites. 9/10<br />Pyramid Song: Largely piano driven and some haunting sounds coming in the background. Ends with a large orchestral crescendo. Had a very little seen but an effective video. A stand-out. 9/10<br />Pulk/Pull Revolving Doors: Quite possibly the strangest track(and most oddly named) track to come out of the Kid A sessions. This is more of a sound experiment than an actual song. Not bad but I usually skip over it. 7/10<br />You And Whose Army?: Thom's vocals are way up front with taunting lyrics (&quot;Come on if you think you can take us on&quot;). Kind of gospel-y ending. Pretty good but I rarely play this. 7.5/10<br />I Might Be Wrong: Another one of the standouts led by a blues-like riff throughout. You can almost understand the lyrics as they're sung very distorted. Ends with quite beautiful chord arpeggios. 8/10<br />Knives Out: the most &quot;traditional&quot; songs on the album and my favorite on here. I've listened to this several times, not a hint of electronica. A quite catchy chorus(and sung very well). 9/10<br />Morning Bell/Amnesiac: A complete re-tooling of one of Kid A's standouts. Accompanied by slow guitar strums rather than guitar, an overhauled version but the lyrics and melody are still the same. While I like this version better than Kid A's, couldn't they record Follow Me Around or True Love Waits? 8/10<br />Dollars and Cents: Very strong bassline and with the string section rising and falling, sometimes overpowering the vocals. A very interesting listen, there's a LOT of stuff on this one, but it's an &quot;ehh&quot; track. 7/10<br />Hunting Bears: Short guitar instrumental. Very odd guitar tone. The guitars must be miked very close cause you can hear the hand movements on the neck. 8/10<br />Like Spinning Plates: Swirling noises at the beginning joined soon by what sounds like backwards guitar playing. Very distorted voice almost like it's being sung backwards as well. A very ominous and weird track. 7/10<br />Life in a Glasshouse: If you're a fan of 20's or 30's big band type stuff with the big trumpets and horns, you'll LOVE this. The track features veteran jazz trumpeter Humphrey Lyttleton. If you thought Kid A was out there, wait till you hear what sounds like classic big band updated. Good stuff. 9/10<br />While Kid A seems like a difficult-yet-cohesive and flowing whole, this feels like a bunch of tracks bunched up together. While most are a bit subpar, songs like the closer, Knives Out and Pyramid Song make this a worthy addition to their catalogue. Just one question: why couldn't they record Follow Me Around?

B000005IU2|5.0|\\"Fun House\\" is truly psychotic, a 36-minute tour de force through pulsing, acidic hardscrabble wrapped in jungle rhythms and Iggy Pop's delirious consortium of mumbles and screams.  Somehow, it makes brutal, rudimentary primitivism sound almost transcendental, a considerable feat that sets it on a truly amazing plane of genius.  This overwhelming, uncompromising genius is twin-edged, as Ron Asheton's blazing, screeching guitarwork is underscored by the rock-solid rhythm section's quasi-Motown selections.  Dave Alexander's bass playing provides most of the melodies, which are strangely hummable and idiosyncratic, their overall quirkiness making \\"Fun House\\" far more multi-faceted and colourful than most hard-rock records.  Iggy's incensed growls make today's screamers and moaners sound trite, and his humourous side (an endless string of sexual references, the hilarity of calling the album's closer a 'blues' song) is priceless.  From the opening blasts of \\"Down on the Street,\\" (which sounds like the Rolling Stones playing metal in the Grand Canyon), to the pummeling \\"1970 (I Feel Alright),\\" to the cacophonous \\"L.A Blues\\" (a white-noise collage never to be matched in its squalling splendor), \\"Fun House\\" is indeed a bloody fun, blistering workout of staggering brilliance.  It slowly builds in intensity from beginning to end, and by its conclusion, one's callused ears are only eager to listen again and again to such a timeless, indestructible racket.

B000092ZYX|5.0|If you are not a Radiohead fan and never have been one, this album will not appeal to you.  For everyone else, this album represents a return to the days of the mid 90s  Radiohead 'rocking out' like on The Bends and Ok Computer.  However, they also are still into the weird experiments that made Kid A and Amnesiac so great.  This album represents a point in Radiohead's career when they want to challenge people yet still give us the guitar rock that made them famous.  The opener 2+2=5 represents this best: after a beginning of drum machine clicks and trippy guitars, the song explodes into every direction.  This song truly represents a return to Radiohead rocking out, something that was promised to us on Amnesiac but never happened.  Other standouts include Sail To The Moon, which is another brilliant Radiohead ballad masterpiece, similiar to Exit Music (For a Film), How To Disappear Completely, and Pyramid Song, Sit Down Stand Up, which to me is up there with Everything In Its Right Place and Fake Plastic Trees as one of the most beautiful Radiohead songs ever, Go To Sleep, which is very Ok Computer-ish, and A Punch Up at a Wedding, in which Radiohead explores jazzy guitar and piano over a drum machine.  I must add that the drum machine programming on this album is done to perfection.  Overall, this record is a modern masterpiece.  Radiohead have finally found a point in between their wild experimental tendencies and their desire to return to guitar rock.  Everyone should go get this and have their faith redemmed in modern music.  This album is a reminder that Radiohead is indeed one of the greatest bands ever and that the future looks extremely bright for them.
0609610570|3.0|Larry Bossidy is clearly a five-star leader, and Ram Charan is a gifted consultant and teacher.  It surprised me that their book didn't work as well as I had hoped.<br />Execution's title confused me.  Hopefully, you won't have that problem.  I thought Execution would be all about how to take a strategy and operating plan and implement them well.  Instead, Part III makes it clear that Execution is about meeting overall financial objectives through being an effective organization in setting strategies and operating plans to serve customers well while building an organization that can implement the plans for outperforming competitors.  Part I, by contrast, makes it sound like Execution is only about implementation, noting that almost all organizations have the same strategies (or can quickly get them from consultants), access the same top talent and can easily acquire and employ competitively effective innovation.<br />I also thought Execution would apply to all business people.  Instead, the context for most of the AlliedSignal (Honeywell International's name when Mr. Bossidy became CEO there the first time)  and General Electric examples which dominate the book is that of the CEO or group executive to whom  divisions report in a large conglomerate.  In this sense, Execution is like reading the latter chapters of Mr. Welch's book, Jack.<br />The main difference between Jack and Execution is that Execution tries to build a framework for the book's concepts while sharing examples (mostly of failure) from other organizations.  Mr. Charan's sections of the book mostly focus on that positioning.  Mr. Bossidy mostly tells about his own experiences at AlliedSignal and Honeywell.  Mr. Bossidy, of course, worked with Mr. Welch at General Electric for many years.  Mr. Bossidy reports that you could take execution for granted at GE, but that it was lacking at AlliedSignal when he arrived.  The two coauthors alternate in providing long monologues on the chapter topics and subtopics.<br />Three aspects of Execution are valuable to almost any business leader:  how to hold a strategy review  (chapter 8), building an organization (chapter 5) and the \\"Dear Jane\\" letter to a new leader (conclusion).<br />For those who would like to become CEOs and heads of divisions of large, disparate organizations, Mr. Bossidy's many anecdotes from his experiences at Honeywell International about how to do the leader's job will provide a valuable model that can be used repeatedly.  In many such organizations, there are no good leadership examples and this book can help fill the gap.<br />Here's the book's structure:<br />Part I:  Why Execution Is Needed<br />Chapter 1.  The Gap Nobody Knows<br />Chapter 2.  The Execution Difference<br />Part II:  The Building Blocks of Execution<br />Chapter 3.  Building Block One:  The Leader's Seven Essential Behaviors<br />Chapter 4.  Building Block Two:  Creating the Framework for Cultural Change<br />Chapter 5.  Building Block Three:  The Job No Leader Should Delegate -- Having the Right People in the Right Place<br />Part III:  The Three Core Processes of Execution<br />Chapter 6.  The People Process: Making the Link with Strategy and Operations<br />Chapter 7.  The Strategy Process:  Making the Link with People and Operations<br />Chapter 8.  How to Conduct a Strategy Review<br />Chapter 9.  The Operations Process:  Making the Link with Strategy and People<br />Conclusion:  Letter to a New Leader<br />Execution addresses these problems.  First, many company and division heads have little knowledge about the businesses or the most important functions and processes needed to prosper.  Boards, for example, often bring in a brilliant person who has performed as a \\"role player\\" elsewhere, and they cannot scale up into the CEO job.  When a company has had poor leadership, its processes and organization also become weak and it's hard to get anything done.  There are several poignant examples including Richard Thoman at Xerox and Richard McGinn at Lucent Technologies.  It's hard to fix that problem.  It took years at AlliedSignal and can be quickly lost (which happened in the two years after he retired the first time).  That's why Mr. Bossidy had to come back to restore execution (as he means it) at Honeywell International.  Lacking these perspectives, the business system is misdirected (see The Fifth Discipline).<br />Second, many leaders make bad assumptions about their circumstances.  Acting on those assumptions makes matters worse.<br />Third, companies plan to pursue strategies for which they lack the processes and organizations to implement.  The strategies need to match the ability to execute.<br />As a solution, you as leader must:<br />\\"--Know your people and your business<br />--Insist on realism<br />--Set clear goals and priorities<br />--Follow through<br />--Reward the doers<br />--Expand people's capabilities<br />--Know yourself.\\"<br />I was uncomfortable with many of the examples.  The unending praise of Dick Brown at EDS didn't seem to make any sense knowing that EDS's stock melted down and he was asked to leave.  He was in big trouble when Execution was written, having encouraged his people to grow by taking on large unprofitable new accounts.  It seems like he might have been executing the wrong strategy, one that couldn't be executed.  Most of the \\"failure\\" examples are anonymous which makes them less credible and less compelling.  Finally, Dell is heralded for executing very well (which it certainly does).  However, in describing how the company has evolved its business model to outperform competitors, Execution fails to notice that its business model innovation has been essential to success.  No competitor has this business model.  Execution's assumption that everyone can have the same strategy ignores research that shows that business model innovation creates unique strategies and superior execution compared to making the old business model and strategy more efficient.<br />Unless you are shooting to be CEO of GE or Honeywell International, I suspect that you would do better to read Good to Great for getting ideas related to improving effectiveness.<br />After you finish this book, ask yourself what one thing you could improve would make the most difference in your organization's performance over the next week, month, quarter, year and three years.an at Xerox and Richard McGinn at Lucent Technologies.  It's hard to fix that problem.  It took years at AlliedSignal and can be quickly lost (which happened in the two years after he retired the first time).  That's why Mr. Bossidy had to come back to restore execution (as he means it) at Honeywell International.  Lacking these perspectives, the business system is misdirected (see The Fifth Discipline).  <br />Second, many leaders make bad assumptions about their circumstances.  Acting on those assumptions makes matters worse.  <br />Third, companies plan to pursue strategies for which they lack the processes and organizations to implement.  The strategies need to match the ability to execute.  <br />As a solution, you as leader must:<br />\\"--Know your people and your business<BR>--Insist on realism<BR>--Set clear goals and priorities<BR>--Follow through<BR>--Reward the doers<BR>--Expand people's capabilities<BR>--Know yourself.\\"<br />I was uncomfortable with many of the examples.  The unending praise of Dick Brown at EDS didn't seem to make any sense knowing that EDS's stock melted down and he was asked to leave.  He was in big trouble when Execution was written, having encouraged his people to grow by taking on large unprofitable new accounts.  It seems like he might have been executing the wrong strategy, one that couldn't be executed.  Most of the \\"failure\\" examples are anonymous which makes them less credible and less compelling.  Finally, Dell is heralded for executing very well (which it certainly does).  However, in describing how the company has evolved its business model to outperform competitors, Execution fails to notice that its business model innovation has been essential to success.  No competitor has this business model.  Execution's assumption that everyone can have the same strategy ignores research that shows that business model innovation creates unique strategies and superior execution compared to making the old business model and strategy moreefficient.  <br />Unless you are shooting to be CEO of GE or Honeywell International, I suspect that you would do better to read Good to Great for getting ideas related to improving effectiveness.  <br />After you finish this book, ask yourself what one thing you could improve would make the most difference in your organization's performance over the next week, month, quarter, year and three years.
B000000W5L|5.0|Since the Rolling Stones are the World's Greatest Rock and Roll Band, they must have made the world's greatest rock album. This right hear is it.  Yes, it is an odd duck for a great album,(only one hit single) but its still the greatest anyway(Only the Stones could record the greatest album in their guitarists basement). I could name eighteen reasons why, but that wouldn't really be true, because what makes Exile so great arn't the individual tracks, but the effect that the album has as a whole. A true work of art the album's murky, almost ugly sound gradually grows on you until you are hooked.<BR>   Rocks Off gets the album off to a bang from the gravely \\"Oh Yeah\\" at the beginning to Jagger's sexual innuendos, to Richards great guitars, to the very cool horns, Rocks Off simply is one of the Stones best openers and one of their best rockers.  Next up is Rip This Joint a freny of frantic Chuck Berry style RNR with humerous shouting from Jagger.  Hip Shake is one of my favorite Stones blues covers. The main riff sounds similar to ZZ Top's La Grange but is quieter with Jagger singing like he is in a trance.  Casino Boogie could be called Exile In A Nutshell because its slow methodical muddy sound which gradually builds up until Richards(I think) finishes things up with a cool guitar solo, completely sums up this albums sound.Also prototypical of Exile you'll notice that some of the lyrics of these first three songs are unable to be understood this happens throughout the album in most of the songs.  To finish side one of the tape is Tumbling Dice, the albums hit single and widely hailed masterpiece. One of Keith's greatest works.  Hear him send out those rich chunky guitar riffs.  I play guitar and can play Tumbling Dice, and it still mystifies me as to how Keith can find such a simple guitar riff and turn it in to a groove that has to be heard to be believed.  Side two brings out another side of the Stones.  It begins with the country blues of Sweet Virginia, my gosh what a chorus, what a harmonica, what a simply beautiful song. Just listen to Mick Taylor's acoustic guitar leads so gentle and flowing. What makes The Stones country songs so awesome is their originality.  They aren't quite authentic country, more like country to a RNR beat, no other band has ever been able to do this before or since.  Anyway, next is Torn And Frayed. One of the most facinating moments on the album. Many of the lyrics are hard to understand but just enough is left to make it clear that this is a quiet country ballad about drug dependency, speciffically Keith Richard's drug dependency.  I wonder if Richards ever recognized himself as the reckless guitar player named Joe described in the song. Sweet Black Angel is a nice folksy tribute to Angela Davis with an outdoorsy sound.  Loving Cup is a love song written for the underdog, as Jagger and Richards plead for a drink from your loving cup.  The second tape begins with Ricards singing in his best singing performance Happy. This is not sung well from a technical point of view but Richards sings and plays with such glee that it soon becomes one of your favorites. Jagger's background vocals supercharges the song.  Turd On The Run is one of those songs that isn't a hook right off the bat but after you hear it 30 times you notice that there is more to this country rambler than just Keith's frantic rhythm. Buried deep and I mean deep in the mix is a very hot lyrical lead guitar by Mick Taylor.  Ventilator Blues moans with desperation and is a much more authentic blues composition than I Got The Blues from Sticky Fingers.  Just Wanna See His Face is mocked by many reviewers but I find it very authentic.\\"Don't wanna walk and talk 'bout Jesus, I just wanna see his face.\\"  Let It Loose is the song that Jaggar is supposed to carry by himself. He does it brilliantly.  The song itself digs back into some of the band's gospel and R&B roots.  The female singer that hangs over at the end sounds so beautiful that I would like to jump into the radio and kiss her on the cheek. Side Four starts with All Down The Line a brilliant rocker that mushes blues, R&B, RNR, and gospel into a little something that I call music.  Stop Breaking Down is another one of the Stones better blues covers, showcased is Jaggars ragged harp, and his ability to sound really mean and ugly, and also Taylor shines with a rough and dirty slide. Shine A Light is about Brian Jones and is perhaps the most beautiful song that I have ever heard before. Jaggar probably sings with more emotion here than anywhere else, Billy Preston gives us the most beautiful chord progressions I have ever heard which sets us up perfectly for two of Taylor's beautiful lyrical guitar solos.  Soul Survivor is another song that mixes everything together in All Down The Line fashion but sounds completely different from ADTL.  Richards bass is hypmotising on this number what a versatile musician when he is on his game. <br />   In conclusion Exile is the best album ever. Though it really is best listened to as a whole but I do have some favorite tracks: Rocks Off, Tumbling Dice, Sweet Virginia, Torn And Frayed, Happy, Turd On The Run, Let It Loose, All Down The Line, Shine A Light, Soul Survivor.

B00000G3Q4|5.0|This was the first \\"Evil Dead\\" movie, and apparently the only one to be conceived as a \\"serious\\" horror film. As such, it tries harder to be creepy and disturbing, while mostly eschewing the wacky humor that took over the sequels. And it works. The plot is minimal: five college students take a trip into the woods to an abandoned (?) cabin and accidentally awaken the forces of the undead, which possesses them one by one and turns them into zombies. The only way to kill such a creature is total bodily dismemberment, hence the fact that the movie was deemed too gory for the MPAA ratings board. For a film shot on such a small budget (reportedly about $300,000), \\"The Evil Dead\\" makes the most of it with ridiculously bloody effects, inventive camera work and enough energy to easily overcome the cheesy acting (although Bruce Campbell is charming as always). It's not as witty or clever as the follow-up, but if you can stand the blood, \\"The Evil Dead\\" offers plenty of chills and thrills.

It also received nominations for Best Supporting Actor (Gary Sinise), Cinematography, Sound, Sound Effects Editing, Make-up and Original Score.<br />Robert Zemeckis will be remembered in addition for his direction of BACK TO THE FUTURE and ROMANCING THE STONE.
B000062YB1|5.0|This is Slayer's best. If you were more into Metallica in the eighties and thought Slayer were too crazy, this is the album for you. It's their most accesible. I usuallly say \\"The heavier the better\\" but this is an exception. It feartures some of their best songwriting ever. this is more a thrash album than a death metal album.
